question: List all the different temperatures that a user has cooked onions. List them with date, temp, and outcome if available.

events.outcome: OK; onion flavor not strong

evidence.excerpt: I put them in a sous vide in about 165 with some butter

events.outcome: not stated

evidence.excerpt: cooking at 145 degrees egg blended with caramelized onions. sous about 4 hours

events.outcome: not stated

evidence.excerpt: second video was me putting that jar in a water bath at 140 something degrees at 141°

events.outcome: At 4 hours the onions were OK but grainy/coarse; onion flavor improved with extended cooking to about 10 hours.

evidence.excerpt: Noted: egg blended with caramelized onions, sous-vide at 145° for about 4 hours.

events.outcome: Avocado oil boosted the onion’s sweetness; flavors more pronounced when combined with the other fats.

evidence.excerpt: I cooked all three for about another hour and 142.5°.

events.outcome: refrigerated overnight; later reheating planned

evidence.excerpt: I had I put the jar of egg and sous vide egg yolk and caramelized onion in the refrigerator overnight. This had been in a sous vide circulator at about 140.5° for maybe 4 to 5 hours.

events.outcome: reheating; yogurt-prep context mentioned

evidence.excerpt: refrigerator overnight and I’m reheating it in a sous vide bath at around 105° because I was already making some yogurt

events.outcome: heat reduced; continued cooking

evidence.excerpt: he reduced the heat to about 136° surface on the pan

events.method: pan-sauté with warming onions and eggs
events.outcome: onion-egg mixture warmed; later raised to higher temp

evidence.excerpt: I scooped out the onion egg mixture the sous vide caramelized onion egg mixture after it had warmed up and I scooped it directly into the eggs after they were cooked a little bit that around and 130° range and 140° range of a pan was a little bit hot

events.outcome: mixture thickened nicely

evidence.excerpt: I actually let it cook at around 150° on the on the surface temperature of the pan and it actually with enough speed in motion it thickened up pretty nicely

events.outcome: color and doneness achieved

evidence.excerpt: and then I briefly took it to 180° on the surface of the pan just to give it some nice color and done ness

events.outcome: onions translucent

evidence.excerpt: It was translucent and but it’s still hard to keep the heat maintained. It’s on low and I’m not sure what to do.

it's in the 160° range and it needs to be in kind of 180° range getting the exact temperature for the heavy bottom pan is on this burner is tricky. I think it needs to be a little above the yellow settingmaybe the one
Got it. You’re aiming for about 180°F in the heavy-bottom pan, currently around 160°F on that left burner.

events.outcome: onions began sizzling directly in the pan after dumping out water; moving toward caramelization

evidence.excerpt: there was too much water because after the onion started to heat up that is they started to release more water and so I had to dump almost all of it out into the pot that I used earlier so that there could be some direct contact with the pan. Now starting to hear the right kind of sizzle on the pan without the water. depends about I think about 190° and I can hear some faint sizzling

events.outcome: inconsistent browning; switched burners to adjust

evidence.excerpt: The pan had gotten up to about 232° and it was causing inconsistent browning. Tried to switch burners.

events.outcome: lower temperature to around 200-205°F with regular stirring; aiming for even browning

evidence.excerpt: Even at a lower temperature once it’s about 200° or probably around 205° anything about that with wires relatively regular motion every minute or so maybe

events.outcome: onions starting to become translucent and have shrunk slightly; lid removed

evidence.excerpt: cooking at about 182 degrees onions are starting to become a little translucent and I think they have shrunk just a little bit. I removed the pot lid

events.outcome: onions browning at times

evidence.excerpt: I took a little bit of a break cause I had to step away from the stove. The onions have become much more brown at times they were cooking at about 210° but then I turned the heat down on average it’s been around 180° I don’t know how much time it’s been cooking for though I think less than two total hours

events.outcome: heat averaging around 180°F; onions browning at times; time unknown

evidence.excerpt: I took a little bit of a break cause I had to step away from the stove. The onions have become much more brown at times they were cooking at about 210° but then I turned the heat down on average it’s been around 180° I don’t know how much time it’s been cooking for though I think less than two total hours

events.outcome: low heat initially; later heat increased toward 270°F with significant browning in some pieces while others remained translucent

evidence.excerpt: i think it was maybe around 165° so then I turned up the heat a little bit from maybe like 2 to 4 on the dial and I stepped away from the pan  and I got real hot real quick and it started to go up to like 270 or somewhere in the 270° range and as you can see there’s significant browning in some of the pieces and still translucent and not very brown in some of the larger pieces

events.outcome: significant browning in some pieces; others still translucent; uneven cooking

evidence.excerpt: turned heat up from ~165°F (dial 2 to 4), spiked to ~270°F, with some onions significantly browned and others still translucent

events.outcome: butter added; temperatures around 229°F; slowed burning and more even heat distribution

evidence.excerpt: temperatures are still around 229° when I checked it and it could’ve been that way for up to a half an hour around then

events.method: heavy bottom pan on left bottom burner, low setting
events.outcome: not at target; aiming for around 180°F

It’s in the 160° range and it needs to be in kind of 180° range getting the exact temperature for the heavy bottom pan is on this burner is tricky. I think it needs to be a little above the yellow settingmaybe the one

events.outcome: not sure what to do; aiming for around 180°F

evidence.excerpt: at the 2 setting it was up to over 200 degrees. there's such a small room for error. not sure what to do

events.outcome: Heat was turned down due to high temperature; cooking continues at lower heat.

evidence.excerpt: I’m caramelizing some onions. They’ve been cooking about 40 minutes; the pan’s surface temperature has ranged 160–200°F, which is a bit high, so I’m turning it down.

events.outcome: Heat was turned down; continuing caramelization.

evidence.excerpt: Got it — you’ve been caramelizing onions for about 40 minutes, with the pan around 160–200°C, and you’re turning the heat down.

events.outcome: LO setting; planning to try a lower setting due to overheating.

evidence.excerpt: Getting the pan right when I getting the pan right is a little tricky so when I have the pan set to the LO setting that’s below two on the left bottom burner the surface temperature of the pan gets hotter. It’s 213°. I think there’s a lower setting that I’m gonna try but that’s way too hot and this is the this is the heavy large pan.

events.temperature: cold storage (refrigeration/freezer; not explicit cooking temp)
events.outcome: flavor and smell were pretty good after defrost

evidence.excerpt: I froze some caramelized onions and I had them in the freezer in a manually vacuumed Ziploc bag for about maybe four or more days opened it up and the flavor and smell was pretty good and that was after about 24 hours of refrigeration defrost

events.outcome: onions translucent

evidence.excerpt: It was translucent and but it’s still hard to keep the heat maintained. It’s on low and I’m not sure what to do.

events.outcome: The bag cooked at 141.5°F was too loose and did not smell very good or taste very good.

evidence.excerpt: One of the bags with caramelized onions were put in sous vide for about more than six hours overnight. One was cooked at 141.5° the other one was cooked at 1:45.5°. They ended up the bag that was 141.5 was too loose and did not smell very good or taste very good the 145.5 was much thicker and the flavor and smell was nicer

events.outcome: The bag cooked at 145.5°F was thicker and the flavor and smell was nicer.

evidence.excerpt: One of the bags with caramelized onions were put in sous vide for about more than six hours overnight. One was cooked at 141.5° the other one was cooked at 1:45.5°. They ended up the bag that was 141.5 was too loose and did not smell very good or taste very good the 145.5 was much thicker and the flavor and smell was nicer

events.method: longer at lower temperature (caramelized onion hollandaise preparation)
events.outcome: Not stated

evidence.excerpt: OK for this next round of caramelized onion hollandaise sauce I’m adding three cubes of frozen caramelized onions so about maybe 6 tablespoons. I kept one large egg yolk and I did about 3 1/2 tablespoons of butter and about a tablespoon of water and added a big pinch of sugar. Going to be this time for longer at a lower temperature about 141°

events.outcome: one egg yolk with about 1.5 tablespoons caramelized onion in a mustard jar

evidence.excerpt: The onion and egg the caramelized onion and egg yolk has been in the sous vide for about 15 hours at 139.5° this is a picture I just emptied some mustard glass jar there’s only one egg yolk in about a tablespoon and a half of caramelized onion

events.outcome: caramelized onions cooked for about 8–10 hours

evidence.excerpt: fresh CHALLAH Hala bread that was just toasted in a pan and some avocado oil from Zach the Baker I spread. I had sous vide eggs and caramelized onions for eight hours no for about 10 hours and then I spread it on the challah toast

events.method: Sieved egg-onion hollandaise into pan and heated to ~143°F
events.outcome: Viscosity high enough to hold a streak; emulsification present; sauce somewhat watery; pinch of sugar brightened flavor

evidence.excerpt: so after being in a after being at about 143° the egg onion hollandaise sauce with a lot more butter and water I put it through a sieve into a pan and you can see that the viscosity is already high enough or thick enough to hold a streak when I pass a a spatula through it and it taste pretty good. It’s also holding up with some emulsification so I mean it’s it seems emulsified but it’s a little watery. Adding a just a pinch of sugar has brightened the flavor a little bit

events.method: Briefly heated the sauce to ~152°F, while attempting to keep around 140°F
events.outcome: Sauce thickened to a nicer consistency and holds shape; flavor slightly improved; onion intensity still subtle; may need more onion next time

evidence.excerpt: I heated the pan up about 152° very briefly taking it on and off the heat trying to keep it at around 140° and that has noticeably thickened up the sauce to a much nicer consistency where it holds a shape and doesn’t completely spread out on the pan the flavor is also improved a little bit but The Onion The Onion is a little too subtle we had about one ice cube tray full of it per egg and I think I may need more

events.outcome: Onions not caramelizing well; difficult to keep pan at 180-200°F; caramelization slows.

evidence.excerpt: most of these photos, deal with me trying to caramelize some onions on the right bottom burner of the heavy bottom pan. Been cooking for about an hour maybe an hour and a half if the temperature drops below about 180° then the caramel then the onions don’t seem to caramelize very well, but it’s difficult to keep the panin the 180 to 200 range

events.outcome: Onions browning in some parts; others remain translucent; uneven caramelization.

evidence.excerpt: in this photo, some parts of the pan are over 200° some parts of the pan are around. I think it was around 184° this you can see from the photo that some of the onions begin to get brown while others stay more translucent, pale yellow.

events.outcome: Onions begin to brown; some areas exceed 200°F; uneven caramelization and risk of burning.

evidence.excerpt: in this photo, some parts of the pan are over 200° some parts of the pan are around. I think it was around 184° this you can see from the photo that some of the onions begin to get brown while others stay more translucent, pale yellow.

events.outcome: Caramelized onions combined with egg yolk; thick jam-like texture; needs salt.

evidence.excerpt: The previous image shows what caramelized onions, previously caramelized onions that were previously frozen and then placed into a bag with egg yolk probably about a one to one ratio of eggs to caramelized onions. It was sous vide in a Ziploc bag at 145.5° for about three hours.

events.outcome: significant browning and softening

evidence.excerpt: I sliced half a large medium onion fried diced dip and I put it probably about a tablespoon of butter and maybe 2 tablespoons of water maybe a little bit more and I cooked it on 375° for maybe three hours although I’m not quite sure and I covered it up in foil with a little but not too tightly wrapped just kind of like a dome at the top. And there was a significant browning and softening

events.outcome: initial browning observed; color progression paused until higher heat applied

evidence.excerpt: so I cooked it for about an hour after putting the oven cooked onions into the pan I started out at around 220° and that had some nice browning I had to stir probably about every couple minutes and add a little splash of water probably about a teaspoon while I was doing it to keep them hydrated but then the color stopped moving much about a half an hour mark I think and that’s when I really kicked up the heat to about between 280 and around 300°

events.outcome: deep brown color developed; viscosity increased with water

evidence.excerpt: that really started because the deep deep brown color was basically happened when it was frying and when I ended it with a with a little bit more water just to increase the viscosity

events.outcome: onions turned translucent with slight browning

evidence.excerpt: onions were softened with about half cup of water then after about 19 minutes with about a tablespoon of butter and higher heat showed at around 240 degrees turning translucent and slight brown.

events.outcome: further softening with brown streaks on the onions; pan changed

evidence.excerpt: pan temperature closer to 250 degrees

events.outcome: mixture turning translucent

evidence.excerpt: sous vide in pot at 142.5 degreedegreess turning translucent

events.outcome: onions browned; resulting sweet nutty butter after straining

evidence.excerpt: I diced up some onions and put it in a small pan and try to keep the temperature to about 250°... it gets brown almost like it’s frying while it’s foaming but it doesn’t burn and the after result is a pretty sweet very nutty butter once it’s strained.

events.outcome: not noticeably brown overall; some brown spots; taste great

evidence.excerpt: sous vide at around 183° it’s been cooking for about 21 to 22 hours and I didn’t pour out some liquid test over that period of time not noticeably brown there’s also a few onions which are the very brown spots taste great

events.outcome: burned

evidence.excerpt: This was a fail the temperature ended up getting at some point around 320° I think more than once in a larger batch of onions and butter and that just burned it.

events.outcome: sides burned parts; uneven browning; necessary stirring

evidence.excerpt: the sides of the pan got up to about 270 but then they started to be burnt parts in the onions you really have to stir a lot and quickly

events.outcome: foam; moisture release; danger; heat reduced

evidence.excerpt: see yeah as there is started to get more foam the temperature the side of the pan reached to 278° and so I think that is one of the dangers as it starts to leak out moisture the temperature climbs very quickly so I’m gonna reduce the heat

events.outcome: observed rapid heat increase; ongoing adjustments

events.outcome: onions softened for about an hour.

evidence.excerpt: Friend onions on white background parchment. These were softened for about an hour at low temperature around 180 degrees then kicked up to around 300 degrees for about 15 minutes. Crunchy and spots of brown around edges or small pieces with larger ones translucent white.

events.outcome: onions developed crunch with brown spots on edges; larger pieces remained translucent.

evidence.excerpt: Crunchy and spots of brown around edges or small pieces with larger ones translucent white.

events.outcome: onions started cooking in a large pan with oil; lid on

evidence.excerpt: Temperature initial temperature was about 92° as measured by an infrared thermometer. Then I covered with a lid. Around 12:16 p.m.

events.outcome: after ~10 minutes, almost nothing happened; pan too cold, no steam

evidence.excerpt: Checked on the onions that were covered in a pan The temperature is about 140° and after it is now 10:27 so after about maybe 10 minutes almost nothing happened because it was just too cold there was there's basically no change no steam no nothing

events.outcome: significant moisture and steam observed after lid lifted/opening lid

evidence.excerpt: Sounds like you got the steam you were aiming for at around 176°F when you lifted the lid. Noted.

events.outcome: browned OK and smelled OK

evidence.excerpt: They browned OK and they smell OK.

events.outcome: color development; browning ongoing

events.outcome: color developing; active caramelization process

evidence.excerpt: I turned up the heat to get a try to get a deeper color some parts of the pan Reed about 220 but I think the real temperature is around 260 and I put splashes of water in maybe about every minute or maybe less to keep it hydrated. At this point it’s a pretty active process.

events.outcome: color developing; flavor bland; butter added

events.outcome: color development; browning ongoing; heat fluctuation
